My first pick for #throwbackthursday is The Lovely Bones by Alice Seabold. This worldwide, bestselling book was first published in 2002 but I didn’t pick it up until 2013. Once I did, I could not put it down, I was absolutely hooked and adored every page. 

It is the heartbreaking story of a 14 year old girl, Susie Salmon (you always know how much a book means to you when you can remember character names without having to look them up!), who is raped and murdered by a neighbourhood man. She is watching the devasting repercussions on her friends and family from heaven whilst trying to come to terms with her own death. 
Beautifully written, this compelling book had me in tears but was also hopeful and humorous which is surprising given the brutality of the subject matter. 

The Lovely Bones was adapted to film in 2009 which I have never been tempted to see in case it ruins the magic of the book for me. 

Have you read or seen The Lovely Bones? What were your thoughts?

this is such a unique book! i was quite excited for this one after my mum told me how much she loved it. it wasn’t what i was expecting but i was definately pleasantly suprised. 

i think it’s powerful in the way it describes the lives of people in mourning... the way it affects families and individuals. i liked the way the author didn’t just describe the actions the characters took but she gets into their minds and shows us WHY they’ve done what they done. you can’t help but feel sorry for everyone despite the events of the book. (minus one character nobody feels sorry for him... if you know... you know) 

this was a beautifully written novel and i think it has some really important morals behind it.

❗️Review: The Lovely Bones, Alice Sebold❗️

Susie Salmon is a 14 y/o girl who was raped & murdered. Now in heaven, Susie narrates the lives of her family & friends in the aftermath of her death 

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ Not many books get me emotional 💔—We Begin At The End & Four Winds are the only books I’ve read to date that have made me tear up 😢 The Lovely Bones is now added to the list. For me, the truly devastating moments were when Susie is watching her parents grieve. Sebold does an amazing job conveying the emotions Susie’s family experiences. Her writing is in a class of its own, which is why I think her book really tugged at my ❤️ when other books haven’t 

I appreciated the version of heaven Sebold creates. She doesn’t get overly religious—I think the focus was on a place that offers closure, connection, & guidance. From Susie’s heaven (bc as we’re told, it looks different for everyone) she’s able to watch down on life, interact & reunite w/ others who’ve arrived, & still have a transitory line of communication w/ her family 

I wanted to read this when it first came out but I was in middle school & prly wouldn’t have appreciated it, so I’m glad I waited. I know it was turned into a movie but I don’t think I’ll watch it—I really like how Sebold’s story looks in my mind & I don’t want the movie to interfere w/ the picture she painted for me. This is a must read & reread forsure!

The Lovely Bones- Alice Sebold
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5

"These were the lovely bones that had grown around my absence: the connections- sometimes tenuous, sometimes made at great cost, but often magnificent- that happened after I was gone. And I began to see things in a way that let me hold the world without me in it.'

This book was a difficult read. I was gripped right from the first sentence, I have never read a book anything like this. 

It is such a powerful book and describes the lives of family and friends in mourning in such a gentle way- it gives us an insight into why some family members made certain choices. All the family members were affected in different ways by the grief of Susie's death and my heart truly went out to all of them especially Susie's Dad- he was seeing his family fall apart in front of his eyes all whilst trying to cope with the death of his first child.

The concept of being able to watch your loved ones after death is one I've never read about before but this book was written in a compelling, unquie way. The idea of Susie having her own "personal heaven" was intriguing. The ending and the part where Susie comes down onto Earth into Ruth's body was.... interesting. 

I keep thinking about how even in Susie's 'perfect world' (heaven), she felt lonely as most of her time was spent observing the living.

Saying that, this book will stay with me for a long time❤️

There’s no better way to spend your 20th birthday than with your favourite people, in a beautiful place, with a gorgeous book (and, of course, getting mega excited to meet my bookish bestie, Hollie!). 

I’ve had a lovely day! I’ve got ice cream ordered and I’m going to curl up with my book and read the night away! It’s so hot where I am that I wanted to make the most of it and take a walk in the stunning areas available to me. I remember walking through the castle grounds as a child, imagining myself in so many different worlds, and now it feels like the perfect place to take everything in.

And, of course, The Lovely Bones is a firm favourite of mine. Susie Salmon deserves the world. The book (and the film) is creepy, dark, and utterly heartbreaking. Read with caution! Always check trigger warnings! But never let other people’s opinions stop you from reading what you love! There are way too many banned books these days. 

Right, I’m stepping off my soapbox now. Happy Wednesday, lovelies! And happy birthday to me!

“If I had but an hour of love, if that be all that is given me, an hour of love upon this earth, I would give my love to thee.”

I have been reading stories as told by the dead in heaven for this week. However, it takes a lot of determination to read a murdered young girl's point of view in the afterlife. While a Mitch Albom book was warm and fuzzy, reading The Lovely Bones was all sadness and misery. Susie Salmon was only fourteen when she got murdered by her neighbor. There is a detailed description of rape from her point of view, which is almost unbearable to read. It is probably the most disturbing book I have ever read in my entire existence. I have never felt so frustrated and uncomfortable while reading a book. Although, The Lovely Bones is not what you consider "lovely", there are still beautiful lessons. 

Never recommend this book to children. Reading rape from a victim's point of view at 18 years old is traumatizing. I made it through the rest of the book in a state of anxiety and near hysteria. I then finished the book in a daze and kept it in the furthest area of my shelf hidden from my sisters. What's even worse was I had to relive my vivid memories of the book when my friends and I decided to watch the movie adaptation yesterday. I am still recovering. 

Short life update, I survived another stressful week. I need to take my time to enjoy the next few weeks of less school work. I'm turning off comments in my posts because I am working on having less screen time🥹 still, thank you so much for the love that I’ve been receiving here on booksta ❤️. I still try keep up with you guys here. Thank you so much for all the tags and challenges. Keep in them coming because I will participate once I'm through with highschool😭☹️. 

Have a beautiful Sunday, friends!❤️✨

BOOK 9️⃣ The Lovely Bones by Alice Seabold ✅ ⭐⭐⭐⭐ 4/5 

📚 Overview: 

"My name was Salmon, like the fish; first name, Susie. I was fourteen when I was murdered on December 6, 1973." 

So begins the story of Susie Salmon, who is adjusting to her new home in heaven, a place that is not at all what she expected, even as she is watching life on earth continue without her -- her friends trading rumors about her disappearance, her killer trying to cover his tracks, her grief-stricken family unraveling. Out of unspeakable tragedy and loss, The Lovely Bones succeeds, miraculously, in building a tale filled with hope, humor, suspense, even joy. 

📚 My opinion: 

The Lovely Bones is a determined reiteration of innocence, a teeth-gritted celebration of something not dismembered or shattered at all, but continuous: the notion of the family unit, dysfunctional, yes, but pure and good nonetheless. It's a celebration that is hard-won, often vivid, sometimes moving, comic and sweet, but that has to be treated with at least a little unease when you consider how the narrative presents us with its villain, the outsider, who is identified by Susie's family by instinct after they simply perceive the man to be a little odd, and after odd, malevolent. 

At the heart of The Lovely Bones is an unwritten book about loneliness and the ways in which a too-perfect world is stifling. 

If I'm honest, I was a little disappointed with the end of the story but still, the narrative was compelling. Definitely worth reading.

📚 Recommended if you enjoy:
- Thriller

❗️I finished The Lovely Bones by Alice Sebold a couple days ago, and I am not a huge fan of giving half stars, but I think I have to do 4.5⭐️. People who are interested in reading should look into the Trigger Warnings beforehand.

🌀I really enjoyed Sebold’s writing and she did a great job in keeping me interested and wanting to read more. I really enjoyed how we slowly learned more even the murderer even though we knew who it was from the beginning. 

😳The reason it lost some stars is I found some of the plot points towards the end to be confusing and for lack of a better word…. icky. I don’t want to give any spoilers, but hopefully those who have read it were as put off by it as I was. But overall really good book.

🎬MOVIE REVIEW: I watched the movie right after finishing the book, and while I understand the book is hard to show in movie form, I was pretty disappointed. The depictions of Susie’s heaven seemed tacky(which I guess could make sense as she is 14years old) and the scene that made me feel icky made even less sense in the movie 😂

~Megan

It’s a heartbreaking story and I wouldn’t exactly say it has a ‘happy’ ending, but there is a sense of closure in some ways.

Another beautiful but haunting read. I first read this whilst doing A-Level English Literature at college and I've reread it a couple of times since. It shocks me every time I do. 

We see how the family sadly falls apart, and how Susie's sister Lindsey's perseverance makes her so much stronger, and how the characters lives are altered and changed so much. It really shows how grief affects everyone so differently; pretending everything is OK, needing to find more answers and never giving up, running away etc. 

I really like the idea of everyone having their own personal "heaven" too, it's a nice conception. I think I'll always love this book but it always makes me so emotional at the end. If you haven't read it, definitely do! 📚🖤🪦

The Lovely Bones

By: Alice Sebold

Finished reading: 18/06/21

I really liked this book! A girl is murdered and from Heaven, watches her family and friends as they grow up and grieve, not knowing who her murderer is. The writing style of this book was so intriguing and elegant; and the characters were created beautifully too. Although at times, it was hard to read because of such dark topics, it was very satisfying to read and finish this book, knowing that by the end, things were better than the beginning. Something else which I loved was the idea of the dead watching their loved ones and helping them; it’s an interesting and positive concept; a better way to grieve, maybe.
